options.content: UCS Chassis Traffic - $chassis in $domain

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Most and least busy service profiles, AKA top-talker and bottom-talker blades

![Chassis Traffic](/public/img/utm/chassis_traffic.png)

**How to use**: Monitor the traffic pattern over time in the graph. Sort by clicking on the avg or current.

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_rx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]] AS "RX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."VnicStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "transport" = 'Eth') AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),transport,service_profile fill(linear)

panels.title: Top Eth traffic - Inbound - per service profile breakdown

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Find links between Fabric Interconnect server ports and fabric ports on IOM in a UCS Chassis

![FI Server Ports to IOM and FEX](/public/img/utm/fi_server_port_to_iom_fabric_port.png)

**How to use**: The table is a quick-reference which can further be used at other places for detailed troubleshooting.

targets.query: SELECT last(oper_state) as "Operational State", channel as "Port-Chanel",peer as "Peer", peer_port as "Peer port", peer_type as "Peer Type", oper_speed as "Speed (Gbps)"  FROM "$db"."$rp"."FIServerPortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/) AND fi_id = 'A' AND channel != '' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY port

panels.title: FI-A Server ports

Use ## for comments and # for configuration. ## The following names are reserved and should not be used (or ignored): ## id, tooltip, placeholder(s), link and label (see below) ## # ## Node label with placeholders and HTML. ## Default is '%name_of_first_column%'. # # label: %name%
%position%
Email # ## Node style (placeholders are replaced once). ## Default is the current style for nodes. # # style: label;image=%image%;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;rounded=1;fillColor=%fill%;strokeColor=%stroke%; # ## Parent style for nodes with child nodes (placeholders are replaced once). # # parentstyle: swimlane;whiteSpace=wrap;html=1;childLayout=stackLayout;horizontal=1;horizontalStack=0;resizeParent=1;resizeLast=0;collapsible=1; # ## Optional column name that contains a reference to a named style in styles. ## Default is the current style for nodes. # # stylename: - # ## JSON for named styles of the form {"name": "style", "name": "style"} where style is a cell style with ## placeholders that are replaced once. # # styles: - # ## Optional column name that contains a reference to a named label in labels. ## Default is the current label. # # labelname: - # ## JSON for named labels of the form {"name": "label", "name": "label"} where label is a cell label with ## placeholders. # # labels: - # ## Uses the given column name as the identity for cells (updates existing cells). ## Default is no identity (empty value or -). # # identity: - # ## Uses the given column name as the parent reference for cells. Default is no parent (empty or -). ## The identity above is used for resolving the reference so it must be specified. # # parent: - # ## Adds a prefix to the identity of cells to make sure they do not collide with existing cells (whose ## IDs are numbers from 0..n, sometimes with a GUID prefix in the context of realtime collaboration). ## Default is csvimport-. # # namespace: csvimport- # ## Connections between rows ("from": source colum, "to": target column). ## Label, style and invert are optional. Defaults are '', current style and false. ## If placeholders are used in the style, they are replaced with data from the source. ## An optional placeholders can be set to target to use data from the target instead. ## In addition to label, an optional fromlabel and tolabel can be used to name the column ## that contains the text for the label in the edges source or target (invert ignored). ## The label is concatenated in the form fromlabel + label + tolabel if all are defined. ## The target column may contain a comma-separated list of values. ## Multiple connect entries are allowed. # # connect: {"from": "manager", "to": "name", "invert": true, "label": "manages", \ # "style": "curved=1;endArrow=blockThin;endFill=1;fontSize=11;"} # connect: {"from": "refs", "to": "id", "style": "curved=1;fontSize=11;"} # ## Node x-coordinate. Possible value is a column name. Default is empty. Layouts will ## override this value. # # left: # ## Node y-coordinate. Possible value is a column name. Default is empty. Layouts will ## override this value. # # top: # ## Node width. Possible value is a number (in px), auto or an @ sign followed by a column ## name that contains the value for the width. Default is auto. # # width: auto # ## Node height. Possible value is a number (in px), auto or an @ sign followed by a column ## name that contains the value for the height. Default is auto. # # height: auto # ## Padding for autosize. Default is 0. # # padding: -12 # ## Comma-separated list of ignored columns for metadata. (These can be ## used for connections and styles but will not be added as metadata.) # # ignore: id,image,fill,stroke,refs,manager # ## Column to be renamed to link attribute (used as link). # # link: url # ## Spacing between nodes. Default is 40. # # nodespacing: 40 # ## Spacing between levels of hierarchical layouts. Default is 100. # # levelspacing: 100 # ## Spacing between parallel edges. Default is 40. Use 0 to disable. # # edgespacing: 40 # ## Name or JSON of layout. Possible values are auto, none, verticaltree, horizontaltree, ## verticalflow, horizontalflow, organic, circle or a JSON string as used in Layout, Apply. ## Default is auto. # # layout: auto # ## ---- CSV below this line. First line are column names. ---- name,position,id,location,manager,email,fill,stroke,refs,url,image Evan Miller,CFO,emi,Office 1,,me@example.com,#dae8fc,#6c8ebf,,https://www.draw.io,https://cdn3.iconfinder.com/data/icons/user-avatars-1/512/users-9-2-128.png Edward Morrison,Brand Manager,emo,Office 2,Evan Miller,me@example.com,#d5e8d4,#82b366,,https://www.draw.io,https://cdn3.iconfinder.com/data/icons/user-avatars-1/512/users-10-3-128.png Ron Donovan,System Admin,rdo,Office 3,Evan Miller,me@example.com,#d5e8d4,#82b366,"emo,tva",https://www.draw.io,https://cdn3.iconfinder.com/data/icons/user-avatars-1/512/users-2-128.png Tessa Valet,HR Director,tva,Office 4,Evan Miller,me@example.com,#d5e8d4,#82b366,,https://www.draw.io,https://cdn3.iconfinder.com/data/icons/user-avatars-1/512/users-3-128.png

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Find links between IOM/FEX backplane ports and server

![Backplane Ports to Adaptor Ports](/public/img/utm/backplane_ports_to_adaptor_ports.png)

**How to use**: The table is a quick-reference which can further be used at other places for detailed troubleshooting.

**Details**: A blade or rack server can have multiple adaptors. Each adaptor may have multiple ports. Each adaptor port has one-to-one connectivity to IOM/FEX backplane port. These connections may or may not be aggregated under a port-channel.

value.title: Details of service profile ${__data.fields[Peer Service Profile]}

targets.query: SELECT bp_port as "Backplane port",last(oper_state) as "Operational State", channel as "Port-Channel", speed as "Speed", peer as "Peer", peer_port as "Peer port", peer_type as "Peer type", peer_service_profile as "Peer Service Profile" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/) AND ("chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/) AND fi_id = 'A' AND channel != '' AND $timeFilter GROUP BY bp_port

panels.title: Backplane ports on [[chassis]] (connected to FI-A)

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Monitor the utilization of IOM backplane ports

![Backplane port utilization](/public/img/utm/chassis_backplane_port_utilization.png)

**How to use**: Start by selecting a UCS domain and chassis. Finally, select a *Backplane port(s)*. The graphs for RX and TX traffic are auto-generated side-by-side. To use the output:
  - Look at Left Y-axis for utilization in (Giga or Mega) bits per second and Right Y-axis for utilization in %.
  - *Util Max* shows max speed of the link. *% Max* always shows 100%.
  - TX traffic on backplane ports is inbound to the blade server. Similarly, RX traffic on backplane ports is outbound from the blade server.

You can select more than one values or All from *Backplane Ports*. The RX and TX graphs are auto-generated for the selected values. You may want to look at everything when you don't know where to start or if you are just doing routine monitoring. But it is better to focus on one link at a time and not get overwhelmed by too much information at the same time.

**Details**: An IOM backplane port has one-to-one connectivity to a single adaptor port on a server. Multiple vNIC/vHBA may be using this link. To find the traffic distribution per vNIC/vHBA, go to the service profile monitoring.
- The options under *Uplink Port Channel* drop-down are automatically updated based on the selected UCS domain and Chassis

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]] AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port,peer_service_profile fill(linear)

SELECT mean("speed") *1000000000 AS "TX MAX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]]/mean("speed")/1000000000 AS "TX % Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

panels.title: Backplane port $bp_port utilization - TX

panels.title: Backplane port $bp_port utilization - TX

panels.description:
**Use Case**: Monitor the utilization of IOM backplane ports

![Backplane port utilization](/public/img/utm/chassis_backplane_port_utilization.png)

**How to use**: Start by selecting a UCS domain and chassis. Finally, select a *Backplane port(s)*. The graphs for RX and TX traffic are auto-generated side-by-side. To use the output:
  - Look at Left Y-axis for utilization in (Giga or Mega) bits per second and Right Y-axis for utilization in %.
  - *Util Max* shows max speed of the link. *% Max* always shows 100%.
  - TX traffic on backplane ports is inbound to the blade server. Similarly, RX traffic on backplane ports is outbound from the blade server.

You can select more than one values or All from *Backplane Ports*. The RX and TX graphs are auto-generated for the selected values. You may want to look at everything when you don't know where to start or if you are just doing routine monitoring. But it is better to focus on one link at a time and not get overwhelmed by too much information at the same time.

**Details**: An IOM backplane port has one-to-one connectivity to a single adaptor port on a server. Multiple vNIC/vHBA may be using this link. To find the traffic distribution per vNIC/vHBA, go to the service profile monitoring.
- The options under *Uplink Port Channel* drop-down are automatically updated based on the selected UCS domain and Chassis

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]] AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port,peer_service_profile fill(linear)

SELECT mean("speed") *1000000000 AS "TX MAX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]]/mean("speed")/1000000000 AS "TX % Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

**Use Case**: Monitor the utilization of IOM backplane ports

![Backplane port utilization](/public/img/utm/chassis_backplane_port_utilization.png)

**How to use**: Start by selecting a UCS domain and chassis. Finally, select a *Backplane port(s)*. The graphs for RX and TX traffic are auto-generated side-by-side. To use the output:
  - Look at Left Y-axis for utilization in (Giga or Mega) bits per second and Right Y-axis for utilization in %.
  - *Util Max* shows max speed of the link. *% Max* always shows 100%.
  - TX traffic on backplane ports is inbound to the blade server. Similarly, RX traffic on backplane ports is outbound from the blade server.

You can select more than one values or All from *Backplane Ports*. The RX and TX graphs are auto-generated for the selected values. You may want to look at everything when you don't know where to start or if you are just doing routine monitoring. But it is better to focus on one link at a time and not get overwhelmed by too much information at the same time.

**Details**: An IOM backplane port has one-to-one connectivity to a single adaptor port on a server. Multiple vNIC/vHBA may be using this link. To find the traffic distribution per vNIC/vHBA, go to the service profile monitoring.
- The options under *Uplink Port Channel* drop-down are automatically updated based on the selected UCS domain and Chassis

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]] AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port,peer_service_profile fill(linear)

SELECT mean("speed") *1000000000 AS "TX MAX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]]/mean("speed")/1000000000 AS "TX % Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

**Use Case**: Monitor the utilization of IOM backplane ports

![Backplane port utilization](/public/img/utm/chassis_backplane_port_utilization.png)

**How to use**: Start by selecting a UCS domain and chassis. Finally, select a *Backplane port(s)*. The graphs for RX and TX traffic are auto-generated side-by-side. To use the output:
  - Look at Left Y-axis for utilization in (Giga or Mega) bits per second and Right Y-axis for utilization in %.
  - *Util Max* shows max speed of the link. *% Max* always shows 100%.
  - TX traffic on backplane ports is inbound to the blade server. Similarly, RX traffic on backplane ports is outbound from the blade server.

You can select more than one values or All from *Backplane Ports*. The RX and TX graphs are auto-generated for the selected values. You may want to look at everything when you don't know where to start or if you are just doing routine monitoring. But it is better to focus on one link at a time and not get overwhelmed by too much information at the same time.

**Details**: An IOM backplane port has one-to-one connectivity to a single adaptor port on a server. Multiple vNIC/vHBA may be using this link. To find the traffic distribution per vNIC/vHBA, go to the service profile monitoring.
- The options under *Uplink Port Channel* drop-down are automatically updated based on the selected UCS domain and Chassis

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]] AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port,peer_service_profile fill(linear)

SELECT mean("speed") *1000000000 AS "TX MAX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]]/mean("speed")/1000000000 AS "TX % Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

**Use Case**: Monitor the utilization of IOM backplane ports

![Backplane port utilization](/public/img/utm/chassis_backplane_port_utilization.png)

**How to use**: Start by selecting a UCS domain and chassis. Finally, select a *Backplane port(s)*. The graphs for RX and TX traffic are auto-generated side-by-side. To use the output:
  - Look at Left Y-axis for utilization in (Giga or Mega) bits per second and Right Y-axis for utilization in %.
  - *Util Max* shows max speed of the link. *% Max* always shows 100%.
  - TX traffic on backplane ports is inbound to the blade server. Similarly, RX traffic on backplane ports is outbound from the blade server.

You can select more than one values or All from *Backplane Ports*. The RX and TX graphs are auto-generated for the selected values. You may want to look at everything when you don't know where to start or if you are just doing routine monitoring. But it is better to focus on one link at a time and not get overwhelmed by too much information at the same time.

**Details**: An IOM backplane port has one-to-one connectivity to a single adaptor port on a server. Multiple vNIC/vHBA may be using this link. To find the traffic distribution per vNIC/vHBA, go to the service profile monitoring.
- The options under *Uplink Port Channel* drop-down are automatically updated based on the selected UCS domain and Chassis

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]] AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port,peer_service_profile fill(linear)

SELECT mean("speed") *1000000000 AS "TX MAX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]]/mean("speed")/1000000000 AS "TX % Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

**Use Case**: Monitor the utilization of IOM backplane ports

![Backplane port utilization](/public/img/utm/chassis_backplane_port_utilization.png)

**How to use**: Start by selecting a UCS domain and chassis. Finally, select a *Backplane port(s)*. The graphs for RX and TX traffic are auto-generated side-by-side. To use the output:
  - Look at Left Y-axis for utilization in (Giga or Mega) bits per second and Right Y-axis for utilization in %.
  - *Util Max* shows max speed of the link. *% Max* always shows 100%.
  - TX traffic on backplane ports is inbound to the blade server. Similarly, RX traffic on backplane ports is outbound from the blade server.

You can select more than one values or All from *Backplane Ports*. The RX and TX graphs are auto-generated for the selected values. You may want to look at everything when you don't know where to start or if you are just doing routine monitoring. But it is better to focus on one link at a time and not get overwhelmed by too much information at the same time.

**Details**: An IOM backplane port has one-to-one connectivity to a single adaptor port on a server. Multiple vNIC/vHBA may be using this link. To find the traffic distribution per vNIC/vHBA, go to the service profile monitoring.
- The options under *Uplink Port Channel* drop-down are automatically updated based on the selected UCS domain and Chassis

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]] AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port,peer_service_profile fill(linear)

SELECT mean("speed") *1000000000 AS "TX MAX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]]/mean("speed")/1000000000 AS "TX % Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

**Use Case**: Monitor the utilization of IOM backplane ports

![Backplane port utilization](/public/img/utm/chassis_backplane_port_utilization.png)

**How to use**: Start by selecting a UCS domain and chassis. Finally, select a *Backplane port(s)*. The graphs for RX and TX traffic are auto-generated side-by-side. To use the output:
  - Look at Left Y-axis for utilization in (Giga or Mega) bits per second and Right Y-axis for utilization in %.
  - *Util Max* shows max speed of the link. *% Max* always shows 100%.
  - TX traffic on backplane ports is inbound to the blade server. Similarly, RX traffic on backplane ports is outbound from the blade server.

You can select more than one values or All from *Backplane Ports*. The RX and TX graphs are auto-generated for the selected values. You may want to look at everything when you don't know where to start or if you are just doing routine monitoring. But it is better to focus on one link at a time and not get overwhelmed by too much information at the same time.

**Details**: An IOM backplane port has one-to-one connectivity to a single adaptor port on a server. Multiple vNIC/vHBA may be using this link. To find the traffic distribution per vNIC/vHBA, go to the service profile monitoring.
- The options under *Uplink Port Channel* drop-down are automatically updated based on the selected UCS domain and Chassis

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]] AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port,peer_service_profile fill(linear)

SELECT mean("speed") *1000000000 AS "TX MAX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]]/mean("speed")/1000000000 AS "TX % Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

**Use Case**: Monitor the utilization of IOM backplane ports

![Backplane port utilization](/public/img/utm/chassis_backplane_port_utilization.png)

**How to use**: Start by selecting a UCS domain and chassis. Finally, select a *Backplane port(s)*. The graphs for RX and TX traffic are auto-generated side-by-side. To use the output:
  - Look at Left Y-axis for utilization in (Giga or Mega) bits per second and Right Y-axis for utilization in %.
  - *Util Max* shows max speed of the link. *% Max* always shows 100%.
  - TX traffic on backplane ports is inbound to the blade server. Similarly, RX traffic on backplane ports is outbound from the blade server.

You can select more than one values or All from *Backplane Ports*. The RX and TX graphs are auto-generated for the selected values. You may want to look at everything when you don't know where to start or if you are just doing routine monitoring. But it is better to focus on one link at a time and not get overwhelmed by too much information at the same time.

**Details**: An IOM backplane port has one-to-one connectivity to a single adaptor port on a server. Multiple vNIC/vHBA may be using this link. To find the traffic distribution per vNIC/vHBA, go to the service profile monitoring.
- The options under *Uplink Port Channel* drop-down are automatically updated based on the selected UCS domain and Chassis

targets.query: SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]] AS "TX Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port,peer_service_profile fill(linear)

SELECT mean("speed") *1000000000 AS "TX MAX" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

SELECT mean("bytes_tx_delta") *8/[[polling_interval]]/mean("speed")/1000000000 AS "TX % Traffic" FROM "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" WHERE ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/ AND "chassis" =~ /^$chassis$/ AND "bp_port" =~ /^$bp_port$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval),bp_port fill(linear)

list.definition: show tag values from "$db"."$rp"."FIEnvStats" with key=domain where $timeFilter
list.label: UCS Domain
list.name: domain
list.query: show tag values from "$db"."$rp"."FIEnvStats" with key=domain where $timeFilter

list.definition: show tag values from "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" with key=chassis where domain =~ /$domain/ and  $timeFilter
list.label: Chassis
list.name: chassis
list.query: show tag values from "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" with key=chassis where domain =~ /$domain/ and  $timeFilter

list.definition: show tag values from "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" with key=bp_port where domain =~ /$domain/ and chassis =~ /$chassis/ and  $timeFilter
list.label: Backplane Ports
list.name: bp_port
list.query: show tag values from "$db"."$rp"."BackplanePortStats" with key=bp_port where domain =~ /$domain/ and chassis =~ /$chassis/ and  $timeFilter

list.definition: select location from (select location,last(load) from "$db"."$rp"."FIEnvStats" where ("domain" =~ /^$domain$/)) where  $timeFilter
list.name: domain_location
